ticket.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state
ticket.original-body:
If there is a race to create a new record for the same ID, and you try to reload, the resulting record is in an inconsistent state.
For example, if two processes do a find_or_initialize_by_id(5) and both come back with new records, then the first process saves, then the second tries and throws a ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. If you rescue that and do record.reload, it will load the record the first process saved, but without clearing the new_record flag. So if you try to save that record in the process that reloaded, it does an insert and throws another ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. The behavior is inconsistent, it should either not allow you to call reload on a new_record, or it should clear the new_record flag if the reload succeeded. The documentation for new_record? says that it returns false if a record for the object doesn't exist yet, which maybe indicates the fix should be to clear the new_record flag.

If there is a race to create a new record for the same ID, and you try to reload, the resulting record is in an inconsistent state.
For example, if two processes do a find_or_initialize_by_id(5) and both come back with new records, then the first process saves, then the second tries and throws a ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. If you rescue that and do record.reload, it will load the record the first process saved, but without clearing the new_record flag. So if you try to save that record in the process that reloaded, it does an insert and throws another ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. The behavior is inconsistent, it should either not allow you to call reload on a new_record, or it should clear the new_record flag if the reload succeeded. The documentation for new_record? says that it returns false if a record for the object doesn't exist yet, which maybe indicates the fix should be to clear the new_record flag.

If there is a race to create a new record for the same ID, and you try to reload, the resulting record is in an inconsistent state.

For example, if two processes do a find_or_initialize_by_id(5) and both come back with new records, then the first process saves, then the second tries and throws a ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. If you rescue that and do record.reload, it will load the record the first process saved, but without clearing the new_record flag. So if you try to save that record in the process that reloaded, it does an insert and throws another ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. The behavior is inconsistent, it should either not allow you to call reload on a new_record, or it should clear the new_record flag if the reload succeeded. The documentation for new_record? says that it returns false if a record for the object doesn't exist yet, which maybe indicates the fix should be to clear the new_record flag.

For example, if two processes do a find_or_initialize_by_id(5) and both come back with new records, then the first process saves, then the second tries and throws a ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. If there is a race to create a new record for the same ID, and you try to reload, the resulting record is in an inconsistent state.

For example, if two processes do a find_or_initialize_by_id(5) and both come back with new records, then the first process saves, then the second tries and throws a ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. If you rescue that and do record.reload, it will load the record the first process saved, but without clearing the new_record flag. So if you try to save that record in the process that reloaded, it does an insert and throws another ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique. The behavior is inconsistent, it should either not allow you to call reload on a new_record, or it should clear the new_record flag if the reload succeeded. The documentation for new_record? says that it returns false if a record for the object doesn't exist yet, which maybe indicates the fix should be to clear the new_record flag.
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: Why on earth are you trying to pick an ID for the record before it's saved? The whole situation has "race condition disaster" written all over it.
version.body-html: Why on earth are you trying to pick an ID for the record before it's saved? The whole situation has "race condition disaster" written all over it.
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: Yes, indeed. Patch welcome for next 2.3 release!
version.body-html: Yes, indeed. Patch welcome for next 2.3 release!
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: Matt, the scenario does have code smell, but it's broken nonetheless :)
version.body-html: Matt, the scenario does have code smell, but it's broken nonetheless :)
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: @matt Facebook application, we use their facebook user id as the id column. When you interact with a friend on the app, their record is created by their ID.
version.body-html: @matt Facebook application, we use their facebook user id as the id column. When you interact with a friend on the app, their record is created by their ID.

version.body: I should clarify that the ID column is not an auto-increment column.

version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: Patch doesn't apply anymore because the relevant code was moved from base.rb to persistence.rb, but the problem still exists. I just tried the test on master and it's still broken. Looking through the code also confirms that new_record is not set to false after successful reload, and save checks "new_record?" and then chooses "create" which does an insert.
version.body-html: Patch doesn't apply anymore because the relevant code was moved from base.rb to persistence.rb, but the problem still exists. I just tried the test on master and it's still broken. Looking through the code also confirms that new_record is not set to false after successful reload, and save checks "new_record?" and then chooses "create" which does an insert.

version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: IMHO, the correct way to fix this would be to not allow reloading of new records at all. After all, the whole idea of reloading is to re-fetch the record from the database and bring it back in sync with the reloaded object. Since a new record is not yet in the database, reloading does not make sense conceptually.
version.body-html: IMHO, the correct way to fix this would be to not allow reloading of new records at all. After all, the whole idea of reloading is to re-fetch the record from the database and bring it back in sync with the reloaded object. Since a new record is not yet in the database, reloading does not make sense conceptually.
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: -1 I agree with David, I don't see the use of reloading a new record.
version.body-html: -1 I agree with David, I don't see the use of reloading a new record.
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body:
I don't disagree. In fact that solution was stated in my original ticket. The reason I patched it the way I did was because my particular use case needed me to fetch the record I thought was new, but wasn't, from the database. So if I didn't do it that way, I'd have to do something like record.replace(Model.find(record.id)).
Whether or not use you a non-auto-increment PK is another argument, but that case is clearly supported. So in conclusion, it's still inconsistent, and either solution will resolve the inconsistency.
version.body-html:
I don't disagree. In fact that solution was stated in my original ticket. The reason I patched it the way I did was because my particular use case needed me to fetch the record I thought was new, but wasn't, from the database. So if I didn't do it that way, I'd have to do something like record.replace(Model.find(record.id)).

Whether or not use you a non-auto-increment PK is another argument, but that case is clearly supported. So in conclusion, it's still inconsistent, and either solution will resolve the inconsistency.
version.title: Reloading a new record results in an inconsistent state

version.body: As far as I'm concerned, I'd rather see #reload raise if passed a new_record?
version.body-html: As far as I'm concerned, I'd rather see #reload raise if passed a new_record?
